sentences.sentence: One morning, about a week after Jane had become engaged( 订婚 ) to Bingley, he and the Bennet girls were sitting together in the dining-room,
when suddenly they heard the sound of a carriage in front of the house.
Bingley instantly persuaded Miss Bennet to take a walk with him outside, in order to avoid anything interrupting their time together.
They both set off.
The remaining three were left to wonder who it was, although with little success, until the door was thrown open and their visitor entered.
It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.
They were of course all expecting to be surprised, but their astonishment( 惊讶 ) was beyond any expectation.
Her attitude when she entered the room was even more arrogant( 傲慢的 ) than usual, and she did not reply to Elizabeth’s greeting except by just slightly nodding her head.
After sitting down for a moment in silence, she said very formally( 正式地 ) to Elizabeth,
“I hope you are well, Miss Bennet.
That lady, I suppose, is your mother.”
Elizabeth replied very briefly that she was.
Mrs. Bennet, with great respect, asked if her ladyship( 夫人 ) would like some refreshment( 点心 ).
Lady Catherine very decisively( 果断地 ), and not very politely, refused.
Standing up, she said to Elizabeth,
“Miss Bennet, I would like to take a walk in your garden, if you will be so kind as to go with me.”
Elizabeth obeyed, and walked downstairs( 楼下 ) with her noble guest.
They continued in silence along the gravel( 铺有碎石的 ) path that led to the garden.
As soon as they entered the garden, Lady Catherine began in the following manner:—
“You can have no doubt, Miss Bennet, about the reason for my journey here.
Your own heart, your own conscience( 良心 ), must tell you why I have come.”
Elizabeth looked at her with true surprise.
“Indeed, you are mistaken, madam( 女士 ).
I cannot understand at all why I have the honor of seeing you here.”
“Miss Bennet,” replied Lady Catherine, in an angry tone( 语气 ), “you ought to know that I will not to be treated like a fool.
However dishonest you may choose to be, I refuse to be so.
Two days ago I heard some very disturbing( 令人不安的 ) news.
I was told that not only was your sister about to be very successfully married, but that you would be soon afterward( 之后 ) also be marrying my own nephew, Mr. Darcy.
Though I know that this must be a disgraceful( 耻辱的 ) lie, I instantly decided to leave for this place, so that I might let you know exactly how I feel.”
“If you believed it could not possibly be true,” said Elizabeth, turning red with surprise and anger,
“I wonder why you took the trouble of coming so far.”
“I will not accept being treated this way. Miss Bennet, I demand that you tell me what I want to know.
Has he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”
“If he has, I will never confess( 承认 ) it.”
“Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? No one ever dares to speak to me like this.
I am one of his closest relatives( 亲戚 ) still living, and I have a right to know about all his most important concerns.”
“But you do not have a right to know mine, and behavior such as this will never force me to reveal( 透露 ) them.”
“Let me make sure that you understand.
This marriage, which you have been so reckless( 不顾一切的 ) in encouraging, can never take place.
No, never. Mr. Darcy is engaged( 订婚 ) to my daughter.
Now what can you still have to say?”
“Only this: that if he is engaged( 订婚 ) to marry her, then you can have no reason to think that he will try to marry me.”
Lady Catherine hesitated( 犹豫 ) for a moment, and then replied:
“Their engagement( 订婚 ) is an unusual one.
From since they were very young, it has been planned that they would be together.
It was what both their mothers wanted.
And now, it is unimaginable that this might be prevented by a young woman of low birth, of no importance in the world, and with no connection to the family!
Did you not hear me say that since his childhood he has been promised to his cousin?”
“Yes, but what does that matter to me?
If you have no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I will certainly not be prevented from doing so by the fact that his mother and aunt wished for him to marry Miss de Bourgh.
You both did as much as you could in planning the marriage, but its completion depended on others.
If Mr. Darcy himself has made no promises to his cousin, then why can he not make another choice?
And if I am that choice, then why may I not accept him?”
“Because honor, prudence( 审慎 ), and self-interest all forbid( 禁止 ) it.
Do not expect to be noticed by his family and friends( 朋友 ) if you defy( 对抗 ) me in this.
You will be despised( 鄙视 ) by everyone connected with him, and your name will never even be mentioned among us.”
“These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth,
“But the wife of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness that she could, on the whole, have no cause to complain( 抱怨 ).”
“Stubborn( 顽固的 ), headstrong( 任性的 ) girl! I am ashamed of you! Let us sit down.
You need to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came here determined to achieve my purpose.
I am not used to giving in to any person’s demands.
I am not well practiced at accepting disappointment.”
“That makes your ladyship’s present situation more pitiable( 可怜的 ), but it will have no effect on me.”
“Tell me once for all, are you engaged( 订婚 ) to him?”
Elizabeth would not have answered this question only for the purpose of satisfying Lady Catherine.
But still she could not help but say, after a moment’s hesitation( 犹豫 ):
“I am not.”
Lady Catherine seemed pleased.
“And will you promise me, that you will never form such an engagement( 订婚 )?”
“I will make no promise of that kind.”
“Miss Bennet, I am shocked and astonished( 惊讶的 ).
I expected to find you a more reasonable young woman.
But do not fool yourself into believing that I will ever stop trying to prevent this marriage.
I will not go away until you have given me the promises I demand.”
“And I certainly will never give you any such promises.
I cannot be frightened into doing anything so totally unreasonable.
I do not know how much your nephew approves( 允许 ) of your interference( 干涉 ) in his life, but you have certainly no right to interfere( 干涉 ) with mine.
I must ask, therefore, that you speak to me no more on this subject.”
“I am not finished yet.
To all the objections I have already mentioned, I have still another to add.
I want you to know that I am completely aware of the details( 细节 ) of your youngest sister’s infamous( 臭名昭著的 ) marriage.
And is such a girl to be my nephew’s sister-in-law? Will our family’s noble heritage( 门第 ) be thus polluted?”
“You can now have nothing more to say,” Elizabeth answered resentfully( 愤恨地 ).
“You have insulted( 侮辱 ) me in every possible way.
I must ask you to return to the house.”
And she stood as she spoke.
Lady Catherine stood also, and they turned back.
Her ladyship( 夫人 ) was highly enraged( 被激怒的 ).
“This is your final decision! Very well.
I now know how to act.
Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that you will ever achieve your purpose.
I came to test you.
I hoped to find you reasonable.
But you can trust me when I say that I will carry out my plans.”
In this manner Lady Catherine continued talking, until they were at the door of the carriage.
Then, turning quickly round, she added,
“I will not say goodbye to you, Miss Bennet. I send no compliments( 问候 ) to your mother.
You deserve no such attention.
I am most seriously displeased.”
Elizabeth made no answer, and without attempting to convince( 说服 ) her ladyship( 夫人 ) to return into the house, she walked quietly into it herself.
She heard the carriage drive away as she walked upstairs( 楼上 ).
Her mother was waiting impatiently( 焦急地 ) for her.
“I suppose she had nothing in particular to say to you, Lizzy?” she asked Elizabeth.
Elizabeth was forced to lie to her mother.
To tell her mother the truth about the conversation was impossible.

article_info.previous: Mr. Bingley再次单独前来拜访，Mrs. Bennet想尽办法创造他们独处的机会。Bingley和Jane敞开心扉，解除了之前的误会。Bingley终于向Jane求婚，Jane欣然答应，所有人都祝福他们。
article_info.share_words: But the wife of Mr. Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness that she could, on the whole, have no cause to complain.

question.cn: 在Jane和Bingley离开后，谁前来拜访了？
question.en: Who was the visitor after Jane and Mr. Bingley left ?

analysis: 文中提到：“They both set off......until the door was thrown open and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Lady Catherine听到了什么令人不安的消息？
question.en: What disturbing news did Lady Catherine hear?

options.en: That Elizabeth would soon be marrying Mr. Wickham.
That Elizabeth would soon be marrying Mr. Darcy.
That Elizabeth would soon be marrying Mr. Bingley.

analysis: 文中Lady Catherine说到：“I was told that not only was your sister about to be very successfully married, but that you would be soon afterward also be marrying my own nephew, Mr. Darcy.” 所以选B。

question.en: What demand did Lady Catherine give to Elizabeth?

options.en: That she must promise not be engaged to Mr. Darcy.
That she must promise to marry Mr. Darcy very soon.
That she must  persuade Jane to leave Bingley.

analysis: 文中提到：“And will you promise me, that you will never form such an engagement?”可知选择A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第97天
